Building a web app to rank my favorite Marvel superhero movies, part I

May 7, 2019

I love superhero movies. Specifically, Marvel superhero movies. Specifically specifically, Marvel Cinematic Universe movies â€” Iron Man, Captain America, Thor, and so on. Never thought Iâ€™d be that guy, but somehow Iâ€™ve seen every single MCU movie â€” 22 in total.

Why? Because theyâ€™re super good! Thereâ€™s a reason they have an average Rotten Tomatoes score of 84%.

But which ones are the best? This is a constant debate among my friends. And with the latest phase of the MCU coming to a close with Avengers: Endgame, itâ€™s been a good time to take stock and make best-of lists.

A few problems, though:

  • There are too many movies. Organizing 22 films in order of preference is aâ€¦ tall order. (ğŸ¥) You have to keep track of every other movie when youâ€™re considering one, or chunk them in ways that could lead to misalignment later.
  • Youâ€™re probably going to give better scores to movies you just saw. Because I watched Avengers: Endgame more recently, Iâ€™m more likely to rate it higher than the original Avengers, just because I remember more details about it.
  • You probably know your favorite and least-favorite films, but nothing in between. This is a twist on the well-documented recency/primacy effect, where humans are better at remembering the beginnings and ends of lists than things in the middle. In this case, fans probably never formed opinions on middling movies, focusing on just the best and the worst.

All of these problems mean tools that let you drag around movie names probably arenâ€™t helping you come up with a definitive list. Theyâ€™re just confusing you!

My take: Itâ€™s easier to pick your favorite movie when you just have two options in front of you. If you run through enough pairings, eventually youâ€™ll get an ordered list.

Thatâ€™s the idea behind mcu.ninja, a ranking tool I put out last week. ğŸ‰

In this post, Iâ€™m going to explain the logic behind the ordering algorithm powering mcu.ninja and the command-line utility I built to demonstrate it. Next week, Iâ€™ll discuss the UI and why I thought Tinder-style swiping was the right decision.

If you just want my MCU movie ranking, here you go.

Sorting is hard

If you need to order a list of 22 items, itâ€™s simplest to go one by one and compare every movie to every other.

Letâ€™s say I start with Captain Marvel. Iâ€™d compare it to Iron Man, the first film in the MCU.

OK, thatâ€™s easy â€”Â I like Iron Man better. But thatâ€™s only the beginning. I still have to compare Captain Marvel to every other MCU movie â€” 21 comparisons in all.

Once weâ€™re done with Captain Marvel, we move on to the next film: Avengers: Endgame. Since we already compared it to Captain Marvel, we donâ€™t have to match them again. But we still have 20 other movies to compare.

So far, weâ€™ve made 41 comparisons. If we add just two more movies, weâ€™re up to 78:

Taking this to its mathematical conclusion, weâ€™d have to make comparisons equal to 21 + 20 + 19 + 18â€¦ + 1, or (n^2 + n) / 2. Thatâ€™s 231 match-ups â€” only marginally better than watching 14,000,605 alternative futures.

Quicksort to the rescue

There are plenty of better ways to sort stuff. In this case, topping the list is the Quicksort algorithm.

Letâ€™s line up all the movies by date released â€” the order doesnâ€™t matter â€”Â and randomly pick Captain Marvel to start:

Captain Marvel is the pivot. Our job is to re-order the list so every movie thatâ€™s worse goes on the left, and every movie thatâ€™s better goes on the right.

It doesnâ€™t matter what order we put them in â€” only that theyâ€™re better or worse than the pivot.

Ater sorting (your choices might be different!), we now know Captain Marvel is No. 16 on list. To do this, we had to make 21 comparisons â€” same as we did before. But the next step is different. We consider the better-than and worse-than movies as their own sets, and run the method again.

So in the â€œworse-than-Captain Marvelâ€ set, we randomly choose Thor: The Dark World as our pivot. In the â€œbetter-than-Captain Marvelâ€ set, we choose Captain America: Civil War. For each of these sets, we again sort the movies by whether or not theyâ€™re worse than the pivot.

Now we have three movies properly ordered â€” with only 40 comparisons, instead of 60 with our previous method. Thatâ€™s a huge improvement.

That kind of efficiency isnâ€™t guaranteed. Quicksort works best when the pivots land in the middle of a given set â€” in this case, the movie thatâ€™s chosen is average, not terrible or spectacular. But unless youâ€™re really unlucky, Quicksort will work far better than brute force.

Building a proof of concept

Before I built out the full mcu.ninja app, I wanted to make sure this method actually made sense. In practice, would it work to present people with pairs of movies and having Quicksort figure out which to show next?

So to test, I built mcu-rankings-cli, a command line interface script written in Node.

Pretty simple â€” it gives you two options, and you pick one. On the back end, I wrote a MovieList class that handled making match-ups and accepting votes from the user. On the front end, the inquirer makes the CLI magic happen.

The method seemed to work pretty well. Sometimes the pivot movies werenâ€™t great â€” itâ€™s annoying to get a stinker like The Incredible Hulk and have to vote against it 20-something times. Later on, I decided to use Rotten Tomatoes data to choose the most â€œaverageâ€ movie in a set as the pivot.

But otherwise, success. Next week, Iâ€™ll talk about how the final swipe-y UI came to be!
